Chapter I 2 1.1 Importance of Renewable Energy in global context Renewable energy has been at the center stage of several global initiatives including Net- zero and Sustainable development. Global leaders have agreed to continue to support the growth of RE through policies and programmes. Business and commerce also appear to roll around the changing trend towards renewable energy. In 2021, China continued to hold the lion's share of the deployment market, contributing 46% of the growth in renewable energy capacity globally [1]. Yearly additions to offshore wind, household solar PV, and biofuels all set new records. For instance, compared to 2020, the number of new offshore wind farms grew nearly six-fold [2]. The European Union was the second-largest market outside of China in terms of added capacity in 2021. Due to project acceleration in Spain, France, Poland, and Germany, which was fueled by a mix of government-led auctions and distributed solar PV subsidies, solar PV alone accounted for the majority of the European Union's expansion [3]. In the US, 24% of the country's utility- scale energy production in the first half of 2022 came from renewable sources compared to 21% during the same time period previous year. Renewable energy was the fastest growing source of power generation in the US [4]. After experiencing a historic slowdown in 2020 as a result of project delays connected to Covid-19 difficulties, India's renewable energy growth picked up in 2021. India's renewable capacity additions in 2021 were more than twice what they were in 2020 because of the commissioning of already-auctioned utility-scale projects and the acceleration of the distributed PV market through the intervention of appropriate policies [3]. There are prominent reasons for the aspiration of accelerated growth of RE whereas, climate change mitigation and self-reliance have been two strong driving factors. The climate change consequence of fossil dependent economy has well been established since decades, but the current state of hardship experienced by the EU nations due to excessive reliance on Russia for their domestic energy needs has been a recent example. 1.2 Broader overview of Renewable Energy in National context India has set ambitious targets for renewable energy deployment over the past few years, with an emphasis on increasing the share of renewables in the country's energy mix. The following are some of the year-wise renewable energy targets that India has set.

Chapter I 3  The government has set a target of achieving 175 GW of renewable energy capacity by 2022, which includes 100 GW of solar power, 60 GW of wind power, 10 GW of bioenergy, and 5 GW of small hydro power [5].  The National Electricity Plan (NEP) envisages achieving a renewable energy capacity of 275 GW by 2025, which includes 140 GW of solar power, 60 GW of wind power, 10 GW of bioenergy, and 5 GW of small hydro power [6].  India's Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) under the Paris Agreement calls for achieving 40% of the country's installed power capacity from non-fossil fuel sources by 2030, which is equivalent to a renewable energy capacity of 450 GW [7].  The government has also set a longer-term target of achieving 500 GW of renewable energy capacity by 2030, which would include a significant expansion of solar and wind power, as well as other forms of renewable energy such as bioenergy, small hydro power, and ocean energy [8]. Government of India’s ambitious target to have 40% power generation capacity based on renewable energy by 2030, with a jump from the existing 150 GW installed capacity to 350 GW would require meticulous planning at all levels in all the contributing regions. Most of the State Governments are planning to increase the share of renewable energy generation capacity so as to achieve the much-needed target. Various schemes and programmes have been initiated by the Government to augment the growth of renewable energy. Chapter I 9 1.2.3 Wind and Small Hydro initiatives: National scenario India has the fourth largest wind installed capacity in the world with a total installed capacity of 41.93 GW as of December, 2022 [19]. By offering different monetary and financial incentives including accelerated depreciation advantages, concessional custom duty exemption on specific components of wind power generators, etc., the government is encouraging private sector investment in wind power projects across the country. Additionally, a Generation Based Incentive (GBI) programme was established for wind energy projects that were started prior to 31 March 2017. The acceleration of wind power is supported through policies like Wind Data Sharing Policy (WDSP) – NISE, National Wind- Solar Hybrid Policy (2018), National Offshore Wind Energy Policy (2016) and Policy for Repowering of the Wind Power Projects (2016). Depending on their sizes, hydropower projects are divided into large and small hydro projects. The size standards used to categorise small hydropower plants (SHP) vary by nation. SHP in India have a capacity less than 25 MW. At present there are no Central Government schemes providing financial support to new projects since 31st March, 2017. Since the use of water resources is a State responsibility, State policies govern how SHP projects are actually carried out. It is evident that renewable energy has made significant inroads into the total energy mix of the country. Due to the inherent variability in the resource potential owing to the associated spatial and temporal parameters, renewable energy based energy generation in different regions depend on different technologies. Successful implementation of these technologies in one region cannot be simply replicated in another region. Identification of region specific potential technologies is the key to promote renewable energy for that region. 1.3 Status of Renewable Energy installations in Assam As seen from Table 1.1 the total renewable energy installed capacity in Assam is 184.03 MW. This is approximately only 10% of the total installed electricity capacity of the State. As per the MNRE assessment solar, biomass and hydro are the primary resources for renewable energy in Assam. Of the total renewable energy capacity, the major contribution has been through solar energy. Bioenergy is a major potential source of renewable energy in the region but this potential has been untapped till now. The growth of policy supported

Considering the potential of bioenergy in the region, the need of a platform that provides precise information on the entire demand-supply chain including biomass resource availability, suitable energy conversion technologies, and site selection is essential. Such plants may be created near these sub stations, preferably by farmers, providing them with an opportunity to raise their income by putting their otherwise unusable land to good use in the form of solar or other renewable energy based power plants. Alternatively, arable land may be put to use if solar power plants were built atop stilts, allowing for the cultivation of crops beneath the structures while still providing RE power to local utility companies. Additionally, the state has faced various challenges in terms of solar deployment, such as lack of adequate infrastructure, transmission, and distribution networks, low levels of investment in the renewable energy sector, and a general lack of awareness and understanding of the benefits of solar energy among the public. However, it is worth noting that Assam has recently announced several measures to promote the development of solar energy in the state. These include a new solar policy with incentives for the development of solar projects, the establishment of a dedicated solar cell to facilitate investment in the sector, and other measures to promote the adoption of solar energy in the state. These initiatives are expected to help accelerate the growth of solar power in Assam in the coming years. According to data from the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE), as of March 2021, Assam had a total installed solar capacity of approximately 47 MW, which is a small fraction of the total solar capacity in India [23]. However, there has been a recent push to increase solar capacity in Assam, and the state government has set a target to install 2,000 MW of solar capacity by 2022. To achieve this target, the Assam government has launched various initiatives, including the Assam Solar Energy Policy, which provides incentives and subsidies for solar power projects, and the establishment of a dedicated solar cell to facilitate investment in the sector. Additionally, the government has launched a program to install solar panels on the rooftops of government buildings, and has also implemented policies to promote the use of solar power in the agriculture sector. While it may take some time to fully realize the target of 2,000 MW of solar capacity in Assam, these initiatives indicate that the state is committed to accelerating the growth of solar energy in the coming years. On a broader perspective, considering the total renewable energy, Assam ranks 24th among the Indian states in the percentage progress of renewable energy installation capacity with an amount of 184.03 MW (refer Table 1.1). Considering the renewable energy generation

Chapter I 14 potential for a natural resource rich State there has been inadequate growth of renewable energy capacity in Assam. There have been major policy interventions, favorable schemes with Government’s initiatives, public awareness campaign etc. to augment the much needed growth of renewable energy in Assam in recent past. It is expected that capacity addition with renewable energy sources should bring positive changes for all the developmental sectors, for all sections of people, and also will be in line with the already declared Sustainable Development Goal of Assam [24]. A critical and thorough assessment of (i) available renewable energy resources in Assam and (ii) associated renewable energy conversion technologies is prerequisite to achieve such rationally desired expectation. There have been many assessments indicating the prospects of generation of renewable energy in Assam using (i) surplus biomass, (ii) solar and (iii) renewable hydropower (small hydro power). In general, land is a primary resource for all types of renewable energy resources. For instance, about 2 ha of land area is required per MW of installed solar power [25-26]. Similarly, residue resources from 10-15 ha crop land area can support 1 MW of biomass power plant [27]. Land is a precious resource and it is linked with economic and livelihood activities of the people. The utilization of land for any purpose should be judiciously planned so as to ensure the much needed development of the people and locality. Thus, a renewable energy development programme, which is fundamentally land intensive, should incorporate the following key aspects in order to promote desired mode of development in Assam. 1.3.1 Key factors for desired growth of RE in Assam (a) Participation of locals: Targeted awareness about the prospects of distributed renewable energy resources among the local people is essential to ensure their participation. The participation of the local population, particularly for a decentralized renewable energy generation, could be ensured if available resources and their inherent characteristics are precisely assessed and shared. Besides getting benefits of indirect employment generation (technology chain, management etc.), formulation of appropriate policy tools could empower the local people to contribute through ownership based on the strengths and limitations of the locally available resources.

Chapter I 15 (b) Assurance of long term and proven sustainability: There are critical environmental (as well as ethical) concerns associated with all industrial activities including the renewable power generation options. For prospective renewable energy generation programme in Assam, the apprehension of such negative concerns should be addressed at the planning stage and must be incorporated during implementation. The precise understanding of the characteristics of the local resources is useful to deal with such apprehensions. (c) Ensuring uniform regional growth: One of the major barriers of adoption of any ideal practice or technology is the inability to visualize the local issues. This happens when a successful model at different region is implemented in a new region with limited understanding of the local dynamics. The renewable energy programme should consider the distributed (and variable) local factors and also align with the Government declared policy tools to defeat regional disparity of growth of renewable energy in Assam. (d) Smart and self-starting: The benefits of modern tools and technologies including the digital technologies should be embodied not only in the planning stage, but also in the implementation stage of renewable energy generation in Assam. For example, the identification of the most profitable route of renewable energy resource utilization, marketing and selling generated power, addressing the environmental concern, dynamic monitoring of the resources availability etc. are key elements of power generation and could be better handled using modern smart digital tools. Moreover, to ensure a dramatic growth of renewable energy system installation and power generation in Assam, the option of energy generation should be attractive to local youths so that Start-ups come up automatically. The proposed road-map for such accelerated growth of renewable energy in Assam is expected to identify all key factors so that renewable energy business becomes smart and self-starting rather than running on Government supports. 1.3.2 Status of existing documents for RE promotion in Assam and their limitations There have been many valuable documents and reports available targeting the favorable growth of renewable energy in Assam [28-31]. State Renewable Energy Action Plan, 2017 indications are useful but lacks specific workable recommendations, perhaps due to absence of precise and high resolution data on resources availability. In the first stage wind resource prospecting is done. The process of prospecting begins with a high-level examination of wind-rich locations. The available information for the region under study or any area within its proximity is analyzed to produce wind statistics based on numerical weather prediction models and reanalysis data. A preliminary wind resource assessment (WRA) is carried out using these data with the intention of comparing regions based on their annual energy output (AEP). The AEP accuracy is +/-50% at this stage. The second stage involves measurement of wind speed at the desired location. The project region must have on-site wind measurements for at least a year. Remote wind measuring and conventional met-masts are two techniques used for on-site wind measurement. In the third stage Linear Wind Flow Model Based Estimation of AEP is carried out. For the main spatial extrapolation and AEP computation, linear wind flow models like WAsP are employed. WindPRO, Wind Farmer, and OpenWind are other pieces of software. The spatial and vertical extrapolations carried out here are applicable for thermal stability (no convection), slightly changing terrain, and terrain where the roughness around the measured sites is comparable to the roughness surrounding the turbine sites. In the event that the stage three model's presumptions are incorrect, computational fluid dynamics (CFD) modelling is carried out. When there is thermal instability and complicated terrain, it is necessary. CFD

Chapter II 33 models are executed on high-performance computer clusters using a three-dimensional grid. Although CFD models increase the cost of a WRA, they are worthwhile when stage three assumptions are not entirely true. Stage five involves loss and uncertainty analysis. This is an important component of a WRA as there exists large scale uncertainty of wind speed measurement, wind speed extrapolation (spatial, vertical and temporal), power curve, wake, air density etc. Based on the estimation of the wind resources in a region, wind power is calculated using standard equations [61]. 2.3.4 Assessment of small hydro power availability In a field where the evaluation methods and information sources have historically been extremely traditional, GIS-based technologies and remote sensing data used to hydropower survey studies have found a place. These methods have been used in several nations to find and select hydropower potential. A procedure for GIS based assessment of hydropower potential involves site identification and flow measurement at chosen sites. The following factors are taken into consideration when choosing a site: (i) Stream order: Only streams of the fifth or higher order should be taken into account to ensure adequate water flow; (ii) Bottom gradient: The chosen site should be such that the average gradient along the bottom of the stream should be 1:50 (i.e., 2%) or more to ensure adequate potential head; and (iii) Minimum hydropower site interval: Distances between two consecutive hydropower sites should not exceed one kilometre. Site selection is based on the Digital Elevation Model (DEM) and stream network. By interpolating contour data, the DEM that describes the terrain features of the study watershed is created. The 20-m interval contour data are taken from typical toposheets. To determine the elevation and subsequently the available drop along the stream bed, the DEM and the stream network are superimposed. From the watershed's outlet, which extends upstream, the search for suitable areas is carried on until it reaches its destination. Based on predetermined criteria, acceptable hydropower sites are chosen. The SWAT2000 hydrological model can be used to estimate flow rate. It can be used for a sizable, rural watershed with more than 100 sub-watersheds that is not gauged. The SWAT model divides a watershed into sub-basins to account for the impact of soil characteristics and land uses on hydrology. The model then separates these sub-basins into more compact, homogenous units called as Hydrologic Response Units (HRU). The HRUs

Chapter II 34 are grouped land areas within the sub-basin with particular characteristics of the soil, land cover, and its management. For the simulation of flow rates, SWAT2000's application needs some particular data. These data fall into two categories: discrete data at a single location and spatial thematic map data. Digital Elevation Model (DEM), stream network data, land use map, and soil map are some examples of spatial thematic map data. Climate data and discharge data are included in the input data for discrete locations. It is necessary to have long-term information about the annual rainfall events that occur close to the study area. The resulting model is then calibrated and validated using standard procedures. The discharges at the designated sites are estimated following model calibration. The estimation of discharge begins at the confluence of two streams and continues until all confluence locations of all streams in the fifth and higher order have been reached. Changes in discharge are disregarded if there are more than two places found between two confluence points that are close to one another. In addition to other purposes, the construction of a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) is a prerequisite for hydropower planning. The model simulates the temporal water flow data during a time for which rainfall and temperature data are available. For all the identified hydroelectric locations, FDC is built using these modelled discharge statistics [33]. 2.4 Best fit renewable energy technology options Technology selection, as discussed earlier, is a critical component for planning renewable energy based energy generation. LULC classification LULC maps are important input data for environmental modelling and water resource management (Steinhausen, 2018). Application of LULC for bioenergy mapping has also been reported in literature (Nataranjan et al., 2016). Both manual and digital methods can be followed for LULC mapping. Digital LULC mapping helps to cover large study areas, minimize labor, cost and time. The digital approach of LULC mapping can be supervised and unsupervised classification. According to Das et al., 2017, in supervised classification, class labels for each data instance in the training dataset is known. In unsupervised classification, data instances are not labelled. Grouping of similar data instances is done based on some specific set of similarity measures. There are many well-established algorithms for supervised classification (e.g., Maximum Likelihood Classifier, Random Forest Classifier) and unsupervised classification (e.g., K-Means Cluster Analysis). In this study, supervised classification method is used for LULC mapping. Both Maximum Likelihood Classifier (MLC) and Random Forest Classifier (RFC) are comparatively applied to determine which method provides better LULC classification for the study area. Prior to LULC classification, the Sentinel 2A image is preprocessed and corrected for atmospheric disturbances, orthorectified and georeferenced to Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) reference system (zone 46N). All the Sentinel-2 spectral bands were resampled to 10 m spectral resolution using the bilinear upsampling method and a mean downsampling method (Tavares et al., 2019). Eight LULC classes were identified for the classification process. Different band combinations were used to distinguish and classify one LULC class from another. On-screen digitization of rice cropland Each individual rice cropland was also manually digitized (on-screen digitization) using ArcGIS software at 1:15000 scale with prior knowledge of the fields. The fallow rice areas appear in light greenish color in RGB mode (band 4:3:2) of Sentinel-2A image. While mapping the cropland, standard guidelines provided by the National Remote Sensing Centre (NRSC, 2006, Hiloidhari and Baruah, 2011) were followed. Annexure VIII Road network mapping The roads were identified and mapped in ArcGIS environment using the Sentinel-2A satellite image. Google Earth was extensively used to identify other types of road (e.g., road passing through fields, roads within a village) in the study area. Field visits and accuracy assessment Randomly selected locations of the study area were personally visited to assess accuracy of the classification. Initially, 42 locations of the study area were selected from the satellite image for the field visit purpose. The locations are evenly distributed and represent each LULC class of the study area. Lat/long coordinates of the visited sites were recorded using handheld GPS and photographs were taken in NEWS direction. Information such as land use type, surrounding land use type, road connectivity and condition were noted down for each of the visited sites. Confusion or error matrices are the commonly used measures for accuracy assessment. A confusion matrix is a cross tabulated sample count of classified map and reference data (Steinhausen et al., 2018). The matrix is used to estimate user’s accuracy, producer’s accuracy, overall accuracy and kappa coefficient (Foody, 2002). The comparison of area under digital and manual classification was done to assess the classification accuracy. Winter cropland Winter vegetables such as cabbage, cauliflower, brinjal, potato are also grown in the study area, but in small amounts. Therefore, winter crop growing areas were mapped as ‘winter cropland’. Land use shared by different winter vegetables could not be mapped separately. Wetland- Wetland rice Some parts of the river Mora Bharali is converted to artificial wetland for fishing and wetland rice cultivation. Those areas were mapped as wetland/wetland rice. The differentiation between wetland and wetland rice areas could not be made because wetland rice areas are not permanent. Wetland rice covers a small part of the river. Depending on depth and water content of the river, the wetland rice areas change from one season to another. Barren land- Fallow land There are no distinct grasslands in the study area as one can observe in a protected forest like a national park. However, there are grass-covered playgrounds in villages, in school and in community areas. Similarly, there is also fallow land (grass-covered in the study area. It is difficult to identify those areas separately using a 10 m image. Therefore they are mapped together as ‘grassland/fallow land’. Assessment of bioenergy potential from rice residues Statistics

available from rice cropland mapping could be used to assess rice residue bioenergy generation potential in the study area. Rice straw and husk has been successfully used as a feedstock for the generation of biomass electricity and 2nd generation biofuel along with the production of other bio-based materials (Hiloidhari et al., 2014; Soam et al., 2016, Chang et a., 2019). Energy potential from rice straw and rice husk available in the study area is estimated as the methodology developed by Hiloidhari et al., 2014. The model considers factors such as residue production ratio (RPR, residue production per unit of grain production), crop area, crop productivity, residue availability factor and energy value of the crop residue. The RPR of rice straw and hush is taken as 1.5 and 0.2. Rice crop productivity in Sonitpur district is taken as 2.15 t ha-1 based on last three years (2016-18) average productivity (MoAFW, 2020). Rice straw and husk availability factors are taken as 0.5 and 0.8 (Hiloidhari and Baruah, 2011). The residue availability factor is the amount of residue available for bioenergy generation after deducing the competing uses (e.g., feed for animal, soil requirement).The LHV of both rice straw and husk is taken as 15.54 MJ kg-1 (Hiloidhari et al., 2014). Results Land use land cover Overall 8 land use classes have been identified, classified and mapped using Sentinel-2A satellite image in the study area of 10 × 10 km2. Both Maximum Likelihood Classifier (MLC) and Random Annexure VIII Forest (RF) classifier have been used for the classification. Results of MLC and RFC classification are presented in Figure 1 and 2. Areas under different land use classes are shown in Table 4. It is observed from Table 4 and Figure 1 and 2 that both the classifiers give different results. The highest difference is observed in built up-settlement areas. The MLC classifier is unable to distinguish properly built up-settlement, sand and barren land-fallow land classes and in most cases these three classes are classified as built up-settlement. It could be suggested that a Sentinel image with 10 m resolution may not be suitable for identification/classification of built up-settlement areas in rural or semi-urban environments. Fusion of Sentinel 1 radar image with Sentinel 2 optimal image can provide better identification of this class (Steinhausen et al., 2018). In rice cropland, area under this class is nearly 8% under MLC and about 10.4% in RFC. There are several locations in the study area where rice cultivation is also practiced in wetland areas, particularly along the Mora Bharali river. Wetland and wetland rice areas could not be identified separately and they were mapped together as wetland-wetland rice class. Area under this class, as per MLC is 8.5% and RFC is 18.1%. Overall, due to these uncertainties, fusion of Sentinel SAR data with Optical data is reported as a solution to increase LULC classification accuracy in rural and semi-urban areas (Steinhausen et al., 2018; Denize et al., 2018).
